name: 9-bromofluorene
Reason: 9-bromofluorene has a melting point that we can compare to fluorene, which has a melting point of 95 degrees Celsius. The bromine atom introduces a significant withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50 degrees Celsius. The additional functional groups and structural features in 9-bromofluorene will affect its melting point: (1) Two phenyl groups, which could each add approximately +20 due to the increase in molecular weight and rigidity of the structure; (2) The tertiary butyl group (C(C)C) is a bulky group which could add about +10 due to steric hindrance and increasing the molecular volume; (3) The piperidine ring (N1CCCC1) and 1-ethyl-4-methylenepiperidine moiety may both add roughly +20 each due to adding more rigid ring structures and making the molecule more compact; (4) The fluorine atom introduces a significant increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +10 degrees Celsius. Summing these modifications gives us an estimated melting point shift.
